ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge of different forms and styles of public/private writing and how they play a significant part in movement and community building. I learned how writers developed such forms, and how students can incorporate these styles into their own writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Super interesting readings and discussions, you develop your writing a lot, you have high engagement with your peers.
Weaknesses: can sometimes feel unorganized

Strengths: class discussions were engaging, readings were insightful and intriguing, and readings were long, but pertinent to course topics and course pacing, the pacing of the final project was perfect and helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. If you have any interest in writing or in race, migration, and ethnicity, this course is a must take.

Tentatively, yes. The readings are great, and the final project can be very fulfilling. However, Professor Mirakhor doesn't always provide the clearest feedback, and it didn't feel like the class was well structured to produce the final project.

Yes, the readings that are assigned are impactful and insightful, the discussions are intriguing, and the project throughout the course really allows students to explore their own form and style in public writing
